Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2015 05:37PM KLynn wrote: Hi ladies....I have a question have any of you had cyber knife on any of your lung tumor mets....I have a consolation tomorrow with a new rad/onc. ... One of my tumor sis 5.2 x 2.2 cm and my doc feels it might just be time to get rid of this one...I still have a few other smaller rumors, but this one is the one he is concerned about....I had RFA of my other lung back a few years ago...and it worked ..nothing has lit up in that area since..only problem with RFA is where the tumor is located...I also had to stay an extra night because I had a small leak...but otherwise it was an easy procedure....much more so than most things I have had done...AND I'm with GatorGal, I had my lung only drain once, it was last March, and it was the most painful thing I have ever had done..I had pockets of fluid so they had to put in leads into the two different spaces...they think they must have rested one on a nerve, because when it started to drain I got such stabbing pain that I couldn't stand it...they gave me all kinds of pain meds, to which I vomited on top of all that pain...I had the sweetest intern that stayed by my bed for 5 hours...he was afraid to leave me...I will NOT have that done again...I I will do everything I have to to prevent any plural effusion again..including this cyber knife if he thinks it will help...and of course my fluid from the plural effusion came back positive for more cancer cells...I can't seem to catch a break...I have been on the boards for years now...taking a break at times..but I have been doing this a very long time..141/2 years since original dx, and 9 years of it being stage 4 ....I'm so tired....anyway...any thoughts on the cyber knife on the lung would be helpful...thanks..K....

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 06:04PM KLynn wrote: Hi Kasey,  Yes it makes so much sense to me..I tried so hard to explain that feeling to my nurses and no one ever understood me..The only way I could explain it was that I wanted to get out of my skin and body..I get the same way, and no one ever knew what it was, first they thought the benydryl, then the hercp., They rushed me in the office from treatment to do an EKG, but I had told them it wasn't my heart, and it wasn't racing, it was just this AWFUL feeling, and you're right it drives you crazy..I now think it was the steriods all along..I found that if I slept when I came home from my treatment, it would make it worse. Happy holidays to you and your family...Hugs KLynn

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 07:52AM KLynn wrote: Hey Ruth,     Wow, I can't believe I just read this, I'm having something very similiar happening right now. I just went for my 3 month scans (I'm also stage 4, in remission at the present time) All scans came back okay except for something going on with my urteres (both sides). Doc says it isn't cancer not to worry but I have an app. for an ultra sound, cat scan, and to see the urologist. They are saying that there is some kind of blockage, but they don't know what, it doesn't look like tumors or stones. (So I'm thinking scar tissue as you have) I have also have some pain with this almost like a UTI, but I had a test and it was neg. I was also on Cipro for a week with no relief.     Now for my history I have not had any raditation to the sternum or ribs, but had radiation 71/2 yrs ago to the right breast area. I was on Gemzar  (besides other chemo drugs) for over a year between 2006 and 2007. I also get herceptin every 3 weeks , I've had many yrs of herc. Just wondering if the Gemzar is the cause of this blockage, and that it builds up in the urteres after time. I know after reading your post I will not be getting a stint thats for sure. I have bleeding problems already and that just doesn't seem  the way to go.      Well, hope all works out for you and you find some relief and comfort. How annoying is this with everything else we go through? My mother had kidney failure due to some of her chemo drugs (also bc) and she had to endure 3 yrs of dyalisis besides going through chemo. I have already told docs I'm not going that route,  believe it or not dyalisis is soooo much worse than going through chemo. That's when I stop all treatments and save the kidneys. Hopefully it doesn't come to that, they say the kidneys look good and plump and normal shape. I'll keep you posted as to what happens with the urologist, which is next week some time. Take care of yourself and hugs to you-------- KLynn

I can tell you that Taxol didn't work for me on my lung mets, then Xeloda didn't seem to be doing the trick either, if it was working, it was very slow and just a terrible drug for me..Then I started on Gemzar, I took it for almost a year.It did work and I have been off of it for about 6 months, I still get herc. every 3 weeks. Posts.Content: KLynn wrote: Hey ladies.... I know I've been a bit quiet here lately, I just seem to not have any extra time on my hands lately...I'm having more surgery on this Friday coming...tried to avoid it at all costs but it seems to be the logical answer at this point...Finally having my ovaries and tubes removed..not sure about the uterus yet (waiting to hear what test results showed)..and probably won't know that until I wake up....Had all my pre-op stuff done last week, and had to go and give my own blood ahead of time just in case...yep, just in case I bleed to near death as I usually do with surgery...They weren't really sure they should take two bags of blood the other day, iron was only at 12.5..so the second bag may not be able to be used, if the iron shows to low anyway..Won't know that until the hospital either...Hoping to not have to use it either way...but some of you may remember, I tend to bleed ( for no reason --other than I pump my blood very hard and very fast)...That would be why I tried to avoid the surgery in the first place, and put up with having lupron for over 3 1/2 yrs.....BUT...last scans showed some slight change in the nodules in my lungs...nothing much but  still change, meaning that the estrogen just isn't stopping enough...After all those shots one would think  I'd be done with estrogen...Only thing we could think of was to get them out finally, oh and start on the tykerb...which has been horrible..down to 2 pills a day instead of 4 because of the side effects...I've had a few days off of the tykerb because of the surgery, and my body feels so much better off than on.... In general I feel kind of crappy since giving my blood the other day, not sure if the iron is just too low, I have black and blue marks all over the place....Seeing my oncologist tomorrow, see what he has to say...Oh...forgot to mention that they sent me for my first bone density test before the surgery, and of course the lupron and probably all the other drugs has put me into osteopenia....Fracture risk moderate for spine, hips and femur...hmmm.....so after all of this we have to address that part of it...I'm sure my bones would be much worse off if my estrogen hadn't been so  high..It's all such a vicious cycle...I'd like to get off this merry go round for a bit, but I guess that's not really the option I want..... Say an extra pray for me tonight that I have any easy surgery, but then again I figure if  I don't wake up from surgery I probably don't even know it..huh ???? Surgery is Friday, my birthday Sat. what the heck was I I thinking when I planned this..??? Oh I know, July starts the beginning of the year with all the new deductibles and co-pays, amazing the things we try to keep straight...and save a few bucks...I'll keep you all up-dated on my results, hey I wonder how much the ovaries and tubes weigh ??? I could be lighter when I get done, dropping a few pounds...Hmmm  Take Care KLynn....xoxox How lucky I was to have known someone, that was so hard to say goodbye to.... Dx Stage IV, 6/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 08:15AM KLynn wrote: HI Marietie,  I'm sorry for your loss,  I wish I had a good answer for  you..I lost my mother (my very best friend) in May of 2006 to B/C. I was at the time fighting my own recour of stage iv b/c...The holidays that year were hard , really hard.. I remember trying to get into the shopping mood, for my children, trying to make it SEEM like Christmas for them. I was in a store, and I don't know what came over me, I looked around and people were laughing and smiling, music, was playing throughout the stoe,  and in through the door came a beautiful mother and daughter holding hands (somewhenre around 50 yr and 25 yrs old). I just couldn't handle it. I wanted to scream "What is the matter with all you people, don't you know we have lost such an improtant  part of this world??? " I thought it best to leave...So I put everything down, and walked out, had mysself the hardest, longest cry one could have...I didn't feel much better that day, BUT I was able to have a nice hooliday with my family and remember her at my own time.. Thinking I would have a better holiday last year, I lost my father in law in Sept.(He was like my own dad--I have known him since I was 16) . So two years in a row of losing parent has been rough,and last year wasn't much better. My point being, not to make you sadder, or this hard for you, But to let you know, that you will have break downs, and days are going to be really hard. It just hits you at the most unexpected times. TAKE THE TIME FOR YOU TO GRIEVE AND DON'T TRY TO PUSH IT AWAY.  Don't apologize to anyone if you need to walk away and have a private cry. In the long run you will get through this.I hope you can find some special, happy times these holidays. I can't even imagine losing a child, my heart aches for you .....My mother was 65 when she passed, i was 45 at that time.I was dx at 38 way too young to have b/c. But your daughter she was only a baby..If you ever need to talk just pm me. Remember all the special times with her, go through pictures and videos, it does help..Hugs and my prayers to you KLynn  I hope this helps some...

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2009 12:15PM KLynn wrote: Hey there Joani, I just had the surgery 4 weeks ago...I had my ovaries and tubes removed, left the uterus alone...I too felt the same way about loosing more female parts, and good ones at that...nothing wrong with them...I was happy too be be getting off of the lupron shots, I had been getting them for over 3 yrs now, and yes the bone pain is constant... The surgery wasn't too bad, the incisons very small, and healled very easy..I was worried a bit about the healing, I don' seem to heal as well, with all the drugs in my body as I use to..The worse part was the gas afterwards...One word of advice--- don't lay flat  for a few days when you get home..make sure you have your pillows propped up, it may not be as comfortable to sleep  but I'm telling you you don't want the gas up under your rib cage..I thought I was having a heart attack the one night...It takes a long time for the body to absorb the gas, it doesn't come out the way you would think.... When I first woke up, ( I won't lie to you ) I had the " oh my gosh what happened to me" feeling, everything hurt...but some really good drugs in the hospital took care of that..and I needed a lot of meds at first, I guess I have built up a tolerance to the pain meds after all these years...I went home the same day, they said I could stay , but I really wanted to go home..Felt much better the next day... You have to be smart and not try to do too much for a couple of weeks..don't push yourself...I am really glad it is done and over with...Hoping it really makes a difference with the estrogen feeding my b/c...We'll seewith the next set of scans...I hd to come off of my tykerb, and held off on one of my herceptin treatment, but was back on everything 2 weeks after the surgery.. Good luck, and yes I have felt that way,,...but I do have to say I am still very much a girly girl ..lol..... Hugs KLynn

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 02:36AM KLynn wrote: Hi Jeanette,     Another no reconstruction here, my story is alittle different, I had my bilateral in 2000, not as many women were doing bilaterals then. My mohter had bc 5 yrs prior, and had only the bc breast removed, so I quess I had time to think about it, and knew I would remove both. I also saw a ps before I had the bilat. but chose not to do it at the same time.Worked out better that way, I had some complications with surgery, and wouldn't have gotten the ps anyway, I would have been so dissappointed if I had finally decided to go that way. Anyway, I never did go for the new breasts, once I healed from the bilat, I figured, I just didn't ever want to have to go under the knife again. I have read so many horror stories about reconstruction and boy there are alot out there. On the other side though, there are women out there with beautiful new healthy breasts. I have never regretted not going for the ps, I where prosteises (sp?)  and most people that know don't even remember, they look so good. Hope this helps some. The site breast free is very good, and very helpful, but if you also go to another site started by one of the ladies here ( Beth - she is very knowledgable) it is breastreconstruction.org I think. It has great information there. Good luck and be healthy...Hugs KLynn

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2007 12:13PM KLynn wrote: Hi Carol, I 'm just around the corner from you in many ways. In NJ. and with lung mets. I was originally dx in 2000. Same thing, had my chemo rads hercpt. surg. you name it I had it. I'm a little younger than you but that doesn't matter much , also her2 ++, and er/pr++. I was feeling fine with no symptoms at all when dx in 2005 with lung mets, just a routine check-up showing rising tumor markers. Doc was on top of it right away (love my doc), I was put back on herceptin again with taxotere, after 3 months no change in spots and markers still slghtly rising. Doc  said time for a change, changed to Xeloda (pills), and I was on that for about 7 months but the se's for me were just too much, I quit the Xeloda even though it was starting to work. Next doc put me on Gemzar (IV) which I've been on now for about 1 yr, with great results, tumor markers have been normal for about 6 months now.  Had all my scans and everything is looking good, still have a few spots that doc thinks are dead cells.Just had PETscan and see doc about that this week, hoping to be coming off of the chemo and only staying on the herceptin. It has been a long journey this time fighting the mets( almost 2 yrs)  the little buggers were a little more stuborn than I would have liked, but if they are gone for now and I get some time off I will be very happy. I wish you luck with your treatments and  a faster recovery, there are many many drugs out there if one doesn't work go on to the next is my point. I'm still here and too busy to not be here, lol. We are here for you .  Hugs and wishes to you KLynn (keep us posted on your journey back to health)

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 08:21PM KLynn wrote: Hi Tina, NO NO NO !!!!!!!  Heres my story short version..I also had very aggressive trip +++ b/c6 of 17 nodes positve ..I was only 38 so they hit me as hard as they could with everything.Chemo,ACand Taxol, then 30 or so raditation treatments, 1 yr. of herceptin trial (back in 2000) and almost 5 yrs.of Tamox...Thats when I had my recur with lung mets.....Doing nothing was never an option... That was Jan 2005, I first recieved 3 months of Taxotere, with no improvement. switched to Xeloda for 7 months but really had a hard time, with allergic reactions, and s/e's..Had dose lowered too many times for it to be effective, but it did start to work on the mets, but very slowly..I asked to switch drugs, and was then given Gemzar. I was on Gemzar for almost a yr, when my scans finally came back, putting  with me into remission. All along during that time I was getting herceptin, and lupron shots. I still get the herc. and lupron but haven't had chemo drugs in almost 1 yr...My lung mets were in both lungs and considered to be many many tiny spots, no tumors of size..I didn't have any signs of the mets, only showed up with my tumor markers.. There are definately drugs available for you, don't let anyone tell you anything other...Do not give up...If you have any question just pm me, I'd be more than happy to help ..If you're not happy with your doc, find another, I don't know what area you live in, but there are many ladies here from all over the world, maybe someone can help you find a good doc..Hugs KLynn

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2009 10:41AM KLynn wrote: Hey there Heartbroken, I'm going through something similar right now...Ughhhh...another thing to think about.... I just went for my first bone density test, believe it or not... I am stage 4 already, but no bone mets ..so far.. My bd test showed loss, and put me into the ospeopenia category..loss at hip , and spine, fracture risk moderate...I haven't been to my onc.yet (got the results early) but I know he was talking about one of the drugs working for bd also...I'm not crazy about the Zometa, since it was one of the drugs that shut my mothers kidneys down...She had bone mets, and was given Zometa monthly, so I'm hoping getting it every 6 months may not effect the kidneys..Have to talk this one over with him... I've been getting lupron shots for over 3 1/2 yrs, now , which I'm sure is the cause of the bone loss.. I'm going in next week to have my ovaries finally removed.which I know will make the situation worse..uggg..My body just keeps producing estrogen no matter what they do..I guess my bones would be a hell of a lot worse it they weren't still producing the esto. It just seems like it is a vicious cycle, one that never stops... I see my  onc next week, so I'll let you know what he thinks, and I see the gyno/onc, (the one removing the ovaries ) next week too, so he may have a different thought..I'll keep you posted... Good luck Klynn

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 01:48PM KLynn wrote: Hey there Tina.....I've had lings mets since Jan of 06....I had too many , and too tiny to do anything about in both lungs for some time...chemo would clear up some of them for a bit, then there would be some progression...I've never really been 'clear' at any point, but down to a few  spots being watched....... QOL not too bad....with all of the tiny spots under control, and only a few growing , they decided to try the RFA about a yr. and a half ago....I only had one spot done, since it was the only one big enough to reach....I, of course had to be a bit of a problem, and had a bleed with that spot...had to stay over night to watch it...but all in all it was a pretty easy procedure compared to most...that spot seems to be stable with no new growth since the rfa...shows up as scar tissue I guess in my scans...since the rfa kills the tumor from the inside out, it leaves a small shell there....Just recent my scans have showed more growth in a few of the spots they have been watching...hmmm...I did go for a consult for the rfa again...he doesn't want to touch them, seems they are in a hard place to get,and still pretty small ... frankly I think I just scare him....with my bleeding....then I went for a consult for cyberknife...again, he feels that adding more radiation, and taking the risk of damaging the lung further isn't worth it, with still having so many tiny spots floating around..he feels it isn't really solving the problem, and thinks chemo meds are the answer...I really feel he is right, at this point I don't really have any effects of the mets in the lungs, no shortness of breath, no infections, so I don't want to damage the lungs anymore than I have to...BUT he said if one or two get too big,causing problems, then he may deal with them....Soooo...I'm getting into a new trial in the middle of Sept....seems to be a drug that is causing 'a big stir"..not sure what drug it is yet ( somehow I think it has to be tdm-1 but not sure)...I have been excepted...but don't know the details yet...all I know is that my doc, is part of some 250 doctors involved in the trials, and has been told that the lung mets are melting away....lets hope so...I'll keep you updated....right now I'm just on my Herceptin, ( which I've been on for over 5yrs. now) and a lower amount of Tykerb....take care...KLynn...hope this helps some..

Posts.Content: KLynn wrote: Hello  Stage 4 ladies, I have a question and hope maybe some of you have "tried" to lose some weight on one of  the commercial diets... If I don't lose some weight before this summer I think I may not leave the house...So..Has anyone tried any of these diets, Jenny Craig, Weight Watcher, Nutria/System? I'm asking stage 4er's because it does make a difference, with whats going on inside, with treatment, meds and never having a break from the drugs... I was always on the thin side, until of course the original dx and the 30 lb gain then...I gained very fast with the first set of treatments, and never was able to get down my weight again..5 yrs. of Tamox didn't help either..I was dx with recur 3 yrs ago, and now really can't lose any weight..Monthly lupron and herceptin doesn't help much... So now that I want to "try" again for the 10th time, I think I'd like to go to a diet center for help..Just not sure which is safe with all of our problems..I'm afraid of too much sodium, too much sulfites, not sure how "their " food will work with the drugs and not feeling good most of the time..I'm too tired most days to even think about dieting, but what the heck I'll give it another try..I know most diets are portion control, and that is not a problem for me, I tend to eat very small meals already.. So.. does anyone have any in-put on any of these diets??? What should I stay away from?? I'm trip +++ and don't want to mess with the estogen levels...I know it will be a one pound a week loss, ughhhh..I was never one to drop quickly, most weeks only a lb or two... I need to lose about  35 lbs. but would be happy with even 25... Thinking about joining a gym too, but thats another  whole  story..I really don't think I have the energy to go and be committed to working out anymore..walking is about the most exercise I get..oh and climbing all these stupid stairs in my new house...what the heck was I thinking??? Thanks for your help.. I always know where to come..hugs KLynn How lucky I was to have known someone, that was so hard to say goodbye to.... Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2007 03:04AM KLynn wrote: Hi Bimmer, I've been reading your posts for some time now,and pray for you and your wife Diane. I am a stage 4 , just recently going into remission.Only God knows for how long, but I'll take it. I recently lost my mother to bc, and I understand the pain you are in as I took care of my mother  during her long fight,and at my house the last few days of her life. I see you have Diane on the patch now, I'm not a nurse but from what I saw with my mother, was that once you have the pain under contol it is best to keep her that way. Don't let the patch wear off, it should be changed every 3 days, but don't take her off of them, they also come in 75 , 50's and 25's. My oncologist told us that the pain is easier to keep under control with constant meds, if you let the pain start again it is much harder to get back under control.I hope that makes sense, I tried not to babble.  I know how hard this on you both, and you are lucky to have each other. I also have a wonderful husband that I worry about all of the time.Diane will worry about you each day shes here, as you do for her. Prayers for you and your family.Blessings-- KLynn

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 01:35PM KLynn wrote: Hi Positivity,, I hope it turns out to be nothing.....The only advise I can give you though is to stay on top of it...don't let doctors "poo poo" you and say you are too young, and it's nothing, if you feel something there...I was 38, and I noticed the slightest dimple on the botttom of my right breast, right under my nipple..I had already had two children so I was hoping it was just my breast reshaping....I had very lumpy dense breasts to begin with, so every month they would go up and down a bit with my cycle...There was one lump that I just knew wasn't right, I went for  a mammo, and I told them to cncentrate on that area mostly, they said nothing was there, I went to my gyno, he felt it, said "it didn't feel like cancer.." What ever that means...I decided to go to a breast surgeon just to make sure and put my mind at ease, he couldn't see it on any of the films but did feel what I was talking about...He tried to drain it with a needle..and that's when I knew things weren't good..SO...I don't mean to scare you, really..I hope everyhtin is good with you and I will say a prayer for you...BUT if you have a gut feeling, and you now that dimple wasn't there before, keep going until you find out what it is...You're young and probably very healthy, so you want to be aggressive.... Good luck sweetie.....keep us updated, there are many wonderful ladies here to help you...Hugs KLynn......
